mainmatter.p: A terminal object in a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C is an object \top⊤\top⊤ of \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C satisfying the following universal property: for any object XXXX in \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, there exists a unique morphism !:X \to \top!:X→⊤!:X \to \top!:X→⊤.
This is a collection of notes on categorical semantics for type theories. The notes are based on the paper by Jason Z.S. Hu and NLab.

frontmatter.title: Categorical Semantics for Type Theories › Introduction

mainmatter.p: Over the last few decades, many type systems are designed for different purposes: general program safety, security, and correctness. The categorical semantics is a collection of methods which define meanings of types and programs in category theory.

Category theory is a branch of mathematics studying an abstract kind of mappings, called morphisms, and their algebraic relations. Its generality serves as a common language for navigating connections between different concepts in different areas. We will first go over some basic concepts in category theory.

frontmatter.title: Categorical Semantics for Type Theories › Basic Category Theory concepts

mainmatter.p: Formally, a definition in category theory consists of two parts: data and axioms. The most basic definition is the category

tree.mainmatter: A category CCCC consists A collection of objects C_0C0C_0C0​ (\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)). A collection C_1C1C_1C1​ (\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)) of morphisms (arrows). For every morphism ffff there are an object s(f)s(f)s(f)s(f) (source, domain) and an object t(f)t(f)t(f)t(f) (target, codomain). For every pair of morphisms f, gf,gf, gf,g such that t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g)t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g), there is a morphism g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f (composition) (Also written gfgfgfgf or f;gf;gf;gf;g). For every object xxxx, there is a morphism \text {id} _xidx\text {id} _xidx​ (or 1_x1x1_x1x​) called identity. The following properties hold: s(g \circ f) = s(f)s(g∘f)=s(f)s(g \circ f) = s(f)s(g∘f)=s(f) and t(g \circ f) = t(g)t(g∘f)=t(g)t(g \circ f) = t(g)t(g∘f)=t(g). s(1_x) = xs(1x)=xs(1_x) = xs(1x​)=x and t(1_x) = xt(1x)=xt(1_x) = xt(1x​)=x. Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘fh \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘f when t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g)t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g), and t(g) = s(h)t(g)=s(h)t(g) = s(h)t(g)=s(h). Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx=ff \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx​=f and \text {id} _y \circ f = fidy∘f=f\text {id} _y \circ f = fidy​∘f=f If the identity map and its axioms are omitted then one speaks of a semicategory.

title.strong: With a family of collections of morphisms

tree.mainmatter: A category CCCC consists A collection of objects C_0C0C_0C0​ (\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)). For every pair of objects x, yx,yx, yx,y, a collection C_1(x, y)C1(x,y)C_1(x, y)C1​(x,y) (\hom _C(x,y)hom⁡C(x,y)\hom _C(x,y)homC​(x,y)) of morphisms from xxxx to yyyy. For each pair of morphisms ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y) and gggg in C_1(y,z)C1(y,z)C_1(y,z)C1​(y,z), a morphism g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f in C_1(x,z)C1(x,z)C_1(x,z)C1​(x,z). called their composition. For each object xxxx, a morphism \text {id} _xidx\text {id} _xidx​ in C_1(x,x)C1(x,x)C_1(x,x)C1​(x,x) called the identity on xxxx. The following properties hold: Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘fh \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘f for all ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y), gggg in C_1(y,z)C1(y,z)C_1(y,z)C1​(y,z), and hhhh in C_1(z,w)C1(z,w)C_1(z,w)C1​(z,w). Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx=ff \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx​=f and \text {id} _y \circ f = fidy∘f=f\text {id} _y \circ f = fidy​∘f=f for all ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y). Usually we write \text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C) for the disjoint union \bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y)⨆x,y∈C0C1(x,y)\bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y)⨆x,y∈C0​​C1​(x,y).

mainmatter.p: We only talk about collections here, which is vague, because we do not specify they are sets or classes. If both objects and morphisms fit in sets, we say the category is small. For a counterexample, the category of all sets is not small. However, all functions between sets can be contained in a set. In this case, the category is locally small. When morphisms between two objects fit in a set, we call the set hom-set.

Since category theory is constructed to study structures and a category is actually a structure, we can talk about the category of all small categories \mathbf {Cat}Cat\mathbf {Cat}Cat. Similar to morphisms, we can define functor between categories.

A functor FFFF from a category CCCC to a category DDDD is a map sending each x \in Cx∈Cx \in Cx∈C to an object F(x) \in DF(x)∈DF(x) \in DF(x)∈D and each morphism f:x \to yf:x→yf:x \to yf:x→y in CCCC to morphism F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y)F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y) in DDDD, such that Composition is preserved: F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f)F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f). Identity is preserved: F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx)=idF(x)F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx​)=idF(x)​.
We can push this idea further by considering functors as objects and natural transformations as morphisms.

Let CCCC and DDDD be categories, the functor category D^CDCD^CDC (or [C,D][C,D][C,D][C,D]) is the category whose objects are functors from CCCC to DDDD. morphisms are natural transformations between functors.

Here we use a commutative diagram to represent a natural transformation. When a diagram commutes, morphisms composed by different paths with the same end points are equal. The following diagram represents the equality that G(f) \circ \alpha _x = \alpha _y \circ F(f)G(f)∘αx=αy∘F(f)G(f) \circ \alpha _x = \alpha _y \circ F(f)G(f)∘αx​=αy​∘F(f).

frontmatter.title: Categorical Semantics for Type Theories › Basic Category Theory Structures

mainmatter.p: Though the theory is already rich by only considering sets and categories, it would not be interesting enough. We want to know a little more about the category that we are working with. To achieve so, we can require some additional structures on the category. A common structure is the cartesian product.

Given any category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, and any set \{ X_i \} _{i \in I}{Xi}i∈I\{ X_i \} _{i \in I}{Xi​}i∈I​ of its objects, the product of all these objects is, if it exists, an object \prod _{i \in I} X_i \in \mathcal {C} ∏i∈IXi∈C \prod _{i \in I} X_i \in \mathcal {C} ∏i∈I​Xi​∈C equipped with morphisms (projections) p_i : \left ( \prod _{i \in I} X_i \right ) \to X_i pi:(∏i∈IXi)→Xi p_i : \left ( \prod _{i \in I} X_i \right ) \to X_i pi​:(i∈I∏​Xi​)→Xi​ for each i \in Ii∈Ii \in Ii∈I, such that it is universal with this property, i.e. such that given any other object Q \in CQ∈CQ \in CQ∈C with morphisms Q \xrightarrow {f_i} X_i Q→fiXi Q \xrightarrow {f_i} X_i Qfi​​Xi​ there is a unique morphism (f_i)_{i \in I} : Q \to \prod _{i \in I} X_i (fi)i∈I:Q→∏i∈IXi (f_i)_{i \in I} : Q \to \prod _{i \in I} X_i (fi​)i∈I​:Q→i∈I∏​Xi​ where the following diagram commutes: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} Q \\ \\ { \prod _{i \in I} X_i} && {X_i} \arrow ["{p_i}", from=3-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{f_i}", from=1-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{(f_i)_{i \in I}}"', from=1-1, to=3-1] \end {tikzcd}
With this definition, it is natural to ask what can serve as a nullary product. The concept is characterized by terminal objects.

A terminal object in a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C is an object \top⊤\top⊤ of \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C satisfying the following universal property: for any object XXXX in \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, there exists a unique morphism !:X \to \top!:X→⊤!:X \to \top!:X→⊤.

When making math statements, we often encounter concepts that are dual to each other. In category theory, this phenomenon is captured by the concept of duality. Intuitively, duality offers us free dual theorem from the original one.
For a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, the opposite category \mathcal {C}^{op}Cop\mathcal {C}^{op}Cop has the same objects as \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C, but the morphisms are reversed.
For example, the product in the opposite category, all universal properties corresponds to a dual concept.

For \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C a category and X, Y \in \text {Ob} { \mathcal {C}}X,Y∈ObCX, Y \in \text {Ob} { \mathcal {C}}X,Y∈ObC, the coproduct is an object X \sqcup YX⊔YX \sqcup YX⊔Y equipped with two morphisms i_X:X \to X \sqcup YiX:X→X⊔Yi_X:X \to X \sqcup YiX​:X→X⊔Y and i_Y:Y \to X \sqcup YiY:Y→X⊔Yi_Y:Y \to X \sqcup YiY​:Y→X⊔Y such that it is universal with this property. That is, for any object ZZZZ and morphisms f:X \to Zf:X→Zf:X \to Zf:X→Z and g:Y \to Zg:Y→Zg:Y \to Zg:Y→Z, there exists a unique morphism \langle f, g \rangle :X \sqcup Y \to Z⟨f,g⟩:X⊔Y→Z\langle f, g \rangle :X \sqcup Y \to Z⟨f,g⟩:X⊔Y→Z such that the following diagram commutes: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} X && {X \sqcup Y} && Y \\ \\ && Z \arrow ["{[f,g]}"', dashed, from=1-3, to=3-3] \arrow ["f"', from=1-1, to=3-3] \arrow ["{i_Y}"', from=1-5, to=1-3] \arrow ["{i_X}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["g", from=1-5, to=3-3] \end {tikzcd}

frontmatter.title: Categorical Semantics for Type Theories › Logic, Types and Categories

mainmatter.p: One important principle in type theory is the Curry-Howard Isomorphism (Propositions as types). It depicts the connection between logic and types. A program can represent a logical argument, and operations in logic find meaningful correspondences in program execution. The principle was later extended with category theory due to Lambek. In his work, he showed a correspondence between STLC and Cartesian Closed Categories (CCC) and revealed the connection between types and categories. The correspondence is called the Curry-Howard-Lambek Isomorphism.

In general, there are two approaches to understand or design a type system: the syntactic view and semantic view.
The syntactic view focuses on the syntactic structure of types and programs. We study about subject reduction, cut elimination and etc, simply by manipulating the syntax. It is usually more direct and easier to understand as it is often conducted via induction on some syntactic structures. And it also suggest algorithms which can be implemented. The disadvantage is that it is limited and hard to proof some properties like normalization.
The semantic appoaches are more powerful in general. It is based on mathematics models of type systems. In exchange of the strength and generality, it is usually harder to understand and heavyweight, requries more intuition of the concepts.

One clasical semantic approach to logic is algebraic logic. A logical system is modeled by some algebraic theory. (often related to lattices and semi-lattices). Famous examples include Boolean algebras for classic propositional logic and Heyting algebras for intuitionistic counterpart. The algebraic logic is a powerful tool to study the properties of logical systems, but has a limitation that all operations are limited in one structured set.
An important result from ategorical semantics could be monads. In Moggi's paper, he showed that monads can be used to model computational effects.

A monad of a category \mathcal {C}C\mathcal {C}C is an endofunctor M: \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C}M:C→CM: \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C}M:C→C with two natural transformations \eta : \text {id} _{ \mathcal {C} } \Rightarrow Mη:idC⇒M\eta : \text {id} _{ \mathcal {C} } \Rightarrow Mη:idC​⇒M and \mu :M^2 \Rightarrow Mμ:M2⇒M\mu :M^2 \Rightarrow Mμ:M2⇒M satisfying the following conditions: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} {M^2(X)} && {M(X)} && {M^2(X)} \\ && {M(X)} \\ \\ & {M^3(X)} && {M^2(X)} \\ & {M^2(X)} && {M(X)} \arrow ["{ \mu _{M(X)}}"', from=4-2, to=5-2] \arrow ["{ \mu _X}", from=5-2, to=5-4] \arrow ["{1_{M(X)}}", from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["{ \mu _X}"', from=1-1, to=2-3] \arrow ["{M( \eta _X)}"', from=1-3, to=1-1] \arrow ["{ \eta _{ M(X)}}", from=1-3, to=1-5] \arrow ["{ \mu _X}", from=1-5, to=2-3] \arrow ["{ \mu _X}", from=4-4, to=5-4] \arrow ["{M( \mu _X)}", from=4-2, to=4-4] \end {tikzcd}
